awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Academic-year Robotics Research for Urban Public College Students
awd_abstract_narration: The MetroBotics REU Site project provides funded academic year research opportunities for students from public urban institutions within the New York City area. The project engages undergraduates in robotics research in the Agents Lab at the City University of New York (CUNY). The Agents Lab focuses on effective coordination of robust human/multi-robot teams. A rough-and-ready, multi-agent approach is taken, in which small, low-cost robots collectively perform exploration tasks. This team-based strategy differs from state-of-the-art systems in which a single expensive, high-end robot is fielded---but if that robot fails, then the entire operation halts. The multi-agent alternative provides redundancy and requires a system that can coordinate in dynamic, uncertain environments, that can adapt to changing team composition, and can interact with an untrained human operator. The MetroBotics project provides opportunities for undergraduates to participate in this research and to experience the investigative process within a vibrant group setting over an extended timeframe. The target population for the MetroBotics project consists of students underserved by traditional REU Sites, frequently underrepresented in computing, who work while taking classes, who are first in their families to pursue higher education, and who take care of parents or who are parents themselves. These aspects present particular difficulties for students interested in research. MetroBotics strives to get motivated students out of mundane jobs and into the lab during the academic year, giving them a context to deepen technical skills acquired in the classroom and direct access to mentors who can support a dialogue concerning research career options.

por.por_cntn:
There are three major goals for the MetroBotics REU Site:
(1) to get motivated students out of mundane jobs and into the lab during the academic year, giving them a context to deepen technical skills acquired in the classroom and direct access to mentors who can support a dialogue concerning research career options;
(2) to provide opportunities for students to apply the scientific method to computing research, experiencing the investigative process within a vibrant group setting over an extended timeframe, from understanding general principles to designing specialized experiments;
and
(3) to explore and evaluate innovative approaches for addressing problems in two areas of research: (a) human interaction with multi-robot teams and (b) human interaction with geographical information systems.

Training Opportunities Provided:
The primary objective of the REU Site is to provide opportunities for personal growth and development for undergraduate students who would not otherwise be able to engage inextended research. REU students met once a week for regular group meetings with the faculty advisors and a graduate student mentor. At these meetings, one or more group members (faculty and/or students) presented and discussed work: either their own results or reviews of others' work. After researching the literature, students worked with faculty to design their own individualized research projects, which included developing research questions, planning and running experiments, analyzing data and reporting outcomes.

At the end of the academic year, most of the students participated in two events. The first event was a Science Fair, held annually at CUNY Brooklyn College each Spring, where students who are engaged in science research present posters. In the first year of this project, one student won a 3rd place "best poster" prize. The second event was a trip to an international academic conference. Some students attended in the summer following their academic-year participation and were able to attend workshops, tutorials and the main conference program.


Technical Results:
(1) It was shown experimentally that a sequential single-item auction used for allocating exploration tasks to a multi-robot team produces a more efficient allocation than a parallel single-item auction or a greedy allocation. In addition, the sequential single-item auction produces a more equitable distribution of tasks amongst team members than the parallel single-item auction.
(2) It was demonstrated that the "Kinect" sensor produces rich sets of range data that can be used for robot navigation tasks which require more sophisticated feedback than simple sonar sensors.
(3) It was shown that a reactive cognitive architecture without "state" (memory) can only be used to control a robot performing simple tasks in simple environments.
(4) It was demonstrated that the Raspberry Pi micro-controller,  Arduino micro-controller and low-cost sonar sensors can be used to build a simple inexpensive robot platform for robotics research.
(5) It was shown that QGIS, an open-source geographical information system, can be enhanced to read data from a database using a standard query language, implemented with the programming language Python, in order to extend the capabilities of users working with the software.

Since this is an REU project, the major impact is on development of human resources, that is, the undergraduate students.
